techniques.name: OS Credential Dumping
techniques.description: Adversaries may attempt to extract credentials from operating systems. OS credential dumping is a process where adversaries obtain credentials from various sources within the operating system.
techniques.mitigation: Limit credential overlap across systems, enforce password policies, implement credential guarding
techniques.detection: Monitor for unusual process access, credential dumping tool usage

techniques.name: Network Service Scanning
techniques.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of services running on remote hosts and local network infrastructure, including those that may be vulnerable to remote software exploits.
techniques.mitigation: Network segmentation, host-based firewalls, intrusion detection systems
techniques.detection: Monitor for network scanning patterns, unusual port connections

techniques.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
techniques.description: Adversaries may attempt to take advantage of a weakness in an Internet-facing computer or program, such as a web server, to gain access to a system.
techniques.mitigation: Input validation, secure coding practices, web application firewalls
techniques.detection: Web application monitoring, anomaly detection, signature-based detection

techniques.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
techniques.description: Adversaries may abuse command and script interpreters to execute commands, scripts, or binaries.
techniques.mitigation: Application whitelisting, script block logging, constrained language mode
techniques.detection: Process monitoring, command-line logging, script execution analysis

techniques.name: File and Directory Discovery
techniques.description: Adversaries may enumerate files and directories or may search in specific locations on a host system for certain information within a file system.
techniques.mitigation: File system permissions, access controls, audit logging
techniques.detection: Monitor file system access, unusual directory traversal patterns

techniques.name: Process Injection
techniques.description: Adversaries may inject code into processes in order to evade process-based defenses as well as possibly elevate privileges.
techniques.mitigation: Code signing, process monitoring, anti-malware protection
techniques.detection: Process creation monitoring, memory protection, behavioral analysis

techniques.name: Valid Accounts
techniques.description: Adversaries may obtain and abuse credentials of existing accounts as a means of gaining Initial Access, Persistence, Privilege Escalation, or Defense Evasion.
techniques.mitigation: Strong password policies, account lockout, multi-factor authentication
techniques.detection: Failed login monitoring, unusual account usage, geographic analysis

techniques.name: Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism
techniques.description: Adversaries may circumvent mechanisms designed to control elevate privileges to gain higher-level permissions.
techniques.mitigation: Least privilege principle, UAC restrictions, sudo configurations
techniques.detection: Privilege escalation monitoring, suspicious process execution
